Description: Body sherd (mended from nine fragments with added plaster) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice with part of cul; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; from top: frieze of short added white vertical strokes above added red band; red band with traces of white above; white and red floral motifs; red band; exterior: painted decoration consisting of lion attacking boar to right (on left, foreparts of lion with top of head lost, red patches on body, fine network of golden-yellow crossing lines on neck and one hind paw; part of boar with red dots all over body, neck and head); elaborate rosettes, short vertical strokes and dotted square as filling ornament; below, band of billets in squares; on cul, guilloche pattern with part of handle frill pattern around handle root (now lost).
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a heavy chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1). The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.182 and belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1924,1201.15. This newly discovered join with 1888,0601.182 calls into question the published inscription in Hutton, C. A. 'Inscriptions on pottery from Naukratis', Classical Review 7, 1893, 83, IV because the iconography from this join makes clear that 1888,0601.182 goes to the left of 1924,1201.15.
